Installation View, Lorem, ispsum: Website Title © artists retain copyright

Feminism vs The Internet, The Importance of Cyberfeminism.

By Jessica Chuong

Website

Abstract

None yet.

Cyberfeminism

Women have to fight for equal/ fair rights and even basic human decency in the real world but of course, it’s a lot better now. However, when it comes to cyberspace, it becomes a lot easier to revert back to misogynistic ignorant thinking and actions. It’s not even just women that are being harassed, it’s also others who identify besides just male or female, those who are struggling with finding their own identity, and members of the LGBTQ community. Cyberspace is so male-dominated. Anything from video games, to algorithms, it’s been honed towards males. Harassment and misogyny have become so normalized on the internet that some don’t even see the issue anymore, stating that we should simply just ignore or mute them, etc. Well, why should we have to put up with that? We should be fighting for a change in this cruel behavior. Fighting against misogyny and male-dominated cyberspace is something we should do. When looking up the term “cyberfeminism” there is no one, clear, defined definition. I’d like to think that it’s because it impacts people in so many different ways. Cyberfeminism is important and it approaches the issues of misogyny, sexism, and identity in cyberspace.

Negative Connotations of Feminism

It’s kind of shocking that the negative stereotypes and images that are associated with feminism haven’t really changed since the 1900s. You’d think that people would grow out of such arrogant and outdated thinking but unfortunately, some things never change. The anti-suffrage movement was a movement from 1908 to 1912 that opposed women’s right to vote because it was “against nature”. The images from the campaign are exactly what the stereotypes from today are saying: ugly, manly, angry, man-hater, etc. These are harmful because it makes people hesitant to identify as a feminist or even speak up about it. In an online space, women come in contact with these stereotypes ever so often. Anywhere from video games to social media, girls always hear/see the same sexist “jokes”, “go back to the kitchen”, “she’s mad”, “you’re probably ugly”, things like that.

  • Impact on women, young girls
        1. There are many confident and talented young women who have a great set of skills with technology
          1. Get harsh judgment from peers and get more comments about them being women than their actual skills.
        2. Agatha Park’s Gangnam Makeover (2020)
          1. Showcases young women’s thoughts of what beauty is over beauty ads in Gangnam stations.
      1. Identity on identity, gender, LGBTQ 
        1. Bev Yockelson’s Hold My Hand… (2020)
          1. Influenced by Donna Haraway’s Cyborg Manifesto 
          2. Was able to try a whole new identity and has more control over it on the internet.
        2. The use of avatars could be used to explore identity in virtual space.
        3. Experiences of those using avatars as a way to experiment
    • Ways misogyny/anti-feminism has been normalized 
        1. Female video game characters are always hypersexualized.
          1. If women look different from the traditional/stereotypical look they get backlash. Ex. Aloy from Horizon Zero Dawn
        2. Telling people to simply disconnect from the internet because it isn’t “real”and this diminishes people’s experiences.
        3. There is discrimination against women at companies that include coding, games, or any of the sort.
          1. Riot Games gender discrimination lawsuit 
        4. Male gamer stereotype and the consequences 
    • Injustice and ignorance in treating people differently due to gender
        1. Toxic gamer culture
          1. Gamergate was made purely to go against feminist progression in games.
          2. What it’s like to be playing as a girl in WOW. 
        2. Cyberviolence such as hacking, trolling, impersonation, etc 
        3. Ways to escape the power structure online
        4. VVAWS study of violence against women in video games
    • The virtual world and non-virtual are intertwined  
        1. Virtual spaces flow into other mediums and forums, online and offline 
        2. Donna Haraway's “Cyborg Manifesto”
          1. Discusses the relationship between gender and technology
          2. “Hybrid of machine and organism, a creature of social reality as well as a creature of fiction”(Haraway).
    • Data systems and algorithms male-biased 
        1. Apple Credit cards got into trouble once users noticed that women were offered smaller lines of credit than men. 
        2. Amazon’s experimental AI recruiting tool was discriminating against women. 
        3. AI gender bias could endanger women’s lives.
          1. Women’s breasts and pregnant bodies aren’t considered “standard” measurements for airbags, seatbelts, etc in cars. 
          2. Gender data gap in health
    • Conclusion
      1. Summarize points of why cyberfeminism is needed.
      2. Just because it’s online, doesn’t mean the world offline won’t be affected.

    Impact on Women and Young Girls

    Impact on Identity, Gender, and LGBTQ

    Ways Misogyny and Anti-Feminism Has Been Normalized

    Injustice and Ignorance In Gender Discrimination

    The Virutal and Non-Virtual are Intertwined

    Data Systems and Algorithms are Male-Biased

    Conclusion

    Disciplines

    Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Studies; Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies: Women's Studies; Other Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies

    wolf vostell and dick higgings, fantastic architecture, (something else press, 1974).
